elements.content: Six new silver(I) double salts containing embedded 1,3-butadiyne-1,4-diide (C4 2–) and various types of ancillary heteroaromatic N-donor ligands, namely [{(Ag2C4)0.5(AgNO3)3(L1)}·H2O] n (1; L1 = 3-chloropyridine), [(Ag2C4)2(AgCF3CO2)9(L1)7(H2O)] n (2; L1 = 3-chloropyridine), [(Ag2C4)2(AgCF3CO2)9(L2)7(H2O)] n (3; L2 = 3-bromopyridine), [{(Ag2C4)(AgCF3CO2)5(L3)1.5(H2O)2}·H2O] n (4; L3 = 2-methylpyrazine), [(Ag2C4)(AgCF3CO2)6(L4)6] (5; L4 = 2-cyanopyridine), and [(Ag2C4)(AgCF3CO2)10(L5)8] (6; L5 = imidazole) have been synthesized and characterized by X-ray crystallography. Complex 1 exhibits a two-dimensional coordination network in which the basic building unit is a [Ag4C4Ag4] aggregate. Isomorphous complexes 2 and 3 feature a composite-chain structure with trifluoroacetate and halogen-substituted pyridine ligands surrounding a columnar silver backbone. Complex 4 is a three-dimensional coordination framework composed of silver columns cross-linked by external silver atoms and 2-methylpyrazine bridges. Complex 5 contains two nearly identical discrete supramolecular clusters, each with its [Ag4C4Ag4] core stabilized by four bridging 2-cyanopyridine ligands and three peripheral trifluoroacetates at each terminal. Complex 6 is composed of somewhat similar but larger discrete supramolecules, with its [Ag4C4Ag4] core stabilized by trifluoroacetate as well as both inner and peripheral bis(imidazole)silver units.

elements.content: The design of discrete and higher-dimensional metal–ligand coordination architectures has attracted much interest in the past few decades due to their wide range of potential applications as electronic, photophysical, and magnetic materials, as well as in catalysis and molecular recognition. In this regard, polynuclear metallosupermolecules have received wide attention, in view of the abundant physicochemical properties that are unique to metal clusters. Notably, organometallic metal–alkynyl complexes are apt to form a multitude of multinuclear cluster aggregates due to the σ- and π-donor nature of the acetylide unit, which bridges multiple metal centers with diverse bonding modes to display intriguing structural diversity and variable molecular structures. These metal–alkynyl cluster complexes have been demonstrated to possess potential applications as nonlinear optical materials, molecular wires, and photoluminescent materials. Furthermore, the study of polynuclear silver(I) compounds has recently come into vogue, as the cohesive argentophilic interaction between silver(I) atoms often leads to the assembly of multinuclear Ag n aggregates with short Ag(I)···Ag(I) contacts.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design of discrete and higher-dimensional metal-ligand coordination architectures has attracted much interest in the past few decades due to their wide range of potential applications as electronic, photophysical, and magnetic materials, as well as in catalysis and molecular recognition. In this regard, polynuclear metallosupermolecules have received wide attention, in view of the abundant physicochemical properties that are unique to metal clusters. Notably, organometallic metal-alkynyl complexes are apt to form a multitude of multinuclear cluster aggregates due to the σ- and π-donor nature of the acetylide unit, which bridges multiple metal centers with diverse bonding modes to display intriguing structural diversity and variable molecular structures. These metal-alkynyl cluster complexes have been demonstrated to possess potential applications as nonlinear optical materials, molecular wires, and photoluminescent materials. Furthermore, the study of polynuclear silver(I) compounds has recently come into vogue, as the cohesive argentophilic interaction between silver(I) atoms often leads to the assembly of multinuclear Ag n  aggregates with short Ag(I)⋅⋅⋅Ag(I) contacts.

elements.content: Over the years sustained effort by us and other research groups has focused on the rational design of supramolecular architectures of different dimensions based on multinuclear silver(I) aggregates containing alkynyl ligands. Our systematic investigation into the synthesis and structure of silver double and multiple salts of Ag2C2 (silver acetylenediide or ethynediide) has resulted in successful examples of controlling structure diversity through the introduction of various coexisting anions and ancillary ligands, such as polyoxometalate, betaine, crown ether, and nitrogen-donor ligands. In contrast, although many silver double and multiple salts of 1,3-butadiyne-1,4-diide C4 2–, a higher homologue of C2 2–, have been successfully synthesized by us by dissolving crude polymeric Ag2C4 in a concentrated aqueous solution of one or more soluble silver salts, and the resulting Ag4⊂CCCC⊃Ag4 moiety was found to act as a new type of metal–ligand supramolecular synthon for the construction of coordination networks, the designed construction of discrete molecules and higher-dimensional coordination architectures based on this multinuclear synthon has not been further explored. This prompted us to introduce various types of nitrogen-containing donor ligands into a reaction system containing Ag2C4 to achieve multidimensional coordination network assembly.

In contrast, although many silver double and multiple salts of 1,3-butadiyne-1,4-diide C4 2-, a higher homologue of C2 2-, have been successfully synthesized by us by dissolving crude polymeric Ag2C4 in a concentrated aqueous solution of one or more soluble silver salts, and the resulting Ag4⊂CCCC⊃Ag4 moiety was found to act as a new type of metal-ligand supramolecular synthon for the construction of coordination networks, the designed construction of discrete molecules and higher-dimensional coordination architectures based on this multinuclear synthon has not been further explored. elements.content: By adding selected nitrogen-heteroaromatic ligands into a concentrated aqueous solution containing Ag2C4 dissolved in silver nitrate or mixed trifluoroacetate/tetrafluoroborate, six new silver cluster compounds, namely [{(Ag2C4)0.5(AgNO3)3(L1)}·H2O] n (1; L1 = 3-chloropyridine), [(Ag2C4)2(AgCF3CO2)9(L1)7(H2O)] n (2; L1 = 3-chloropyridine), [(Ag2C4)2(AgCF3CO2)9(L2)7(H2O)] n (3; L2 = 3-bromopyridine), [{(Ag2C4)(Ag­CF3CO2)5­(L3)1.5­(H2O)2}·H2O] n (4; L3 = 2-methylpyrazine), [(Ag2C4)(AgCF3CO2)6(L4)6] (5; L4 = 2-cyanopyridine), and [(Ag2C4)(AgCF3CO2)10(L5)8] (6; L5 = imidazole), have been synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray analysis. Discrete molecules and coordination polymers of different dimensionalities are obtained through silver(I)–N coordination with the Ag4⊂CCCC⊃Ag4 supramolecular synthon acting as a structure-building unit, and further supramolecular assembly is made possible by hydrogen bonding.

elements.content: All chemicals obtained from commercial sources were of analytically pure grade and were used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Nicolet Impact 420 FTIR spectrometer as KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm–1 at a resolution of 2 cm–1. Elemental analysis (C, H, N) was performed by the Analysis and Testing Center of Shanghai Institute of Organic Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Melting points (uncorrected) were measured with a Reichert apparatus in degrees Celsius. Ag2C4 was prepared as described previously.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Reagents and Instruments

All chemicals obtained from commercial sources were of analytically pure grade and were used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Nicolet Impact 420 FTIR spectrometer as KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 at a resolution of 2 cm-1. Elemental analysis (C, H, N) was performed by the Analysis and Testing Center of Shanghai Institute of Organic Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Melting points (uncorrected) were measured with a Reichert apparatus in degrees Celsius. Ag2C4 was prepared as described previously.

elements.content:
Caution! Ag2C4 should be stored wet in the dark at −10 °C, and only a small quantity should be used for subsequent synthesis.

[{(Ag<sub>2</sub>C<sub>4</sub>)<sub>0.5</sub>(AgNO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub>(L1)}·H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>; L1 = 3-Chloropyridine)

Moist Ag2C4 (∼110 mg) was added to a concentrated aqueous solution (1 mL) of AgNO3 (0.44 g, 2 mmol) in a beaker, and the mixture was stirred until the solution reached saturation. The excess Ag2C4 was filtered off, and a few drops of 3-chloropyridine were added to the filtrate. The solution was then placed in a refrigerator at −10 °C. After a few days, transparent yellow platelike crystals of 1 (∼65%) were deposited and collected. Compound 1 decomposes above 93 °C. IR: ν 2065 cm–1 (w, νCC). Anal. Calcd for C7H6Ag4ClN4O10 (M r = 773.09): C, 10.88; H, 0.78; N, 7.25. Found: C, 11.35; H, 0.92; N, 7.58.

elements.content: Crystal data were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å) at 293(2) K. The intensities were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors, as well as for absorption by the multiscan method. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELX-97, and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. For compound 3, bromine atom Br6 is disordered over two positions and refined with an assigned site occupancy ratio of 0.5:0.5. For 4, silver atom Ag7 and one independent 2-methylpyrazine ligand are each located at an inversion center, so that the 2-methyl substituent of the latter is disordered over two sites; furthermore, silver atom Ag1 exhibits disorder over two positions, each with half site occupancy. In addition, a CF3 moiety (F10, F11, F12, F10′, F11′, F12′) of a trifluoroacetate group exhibits orientational disorder. For 6, there are two kinds of discrete molecules which are labeled A and B, with A located in a general position and B at a crystallographic center of symmetry. In molecule A, Ag9, Ag10, Ag11, and Ag12 are each assigned half site occupancy in least-squares refinement, and the pair of imidazole ligands that coordinate to each of them exhibit orientational disorder such that the ligating N atom and an adjacent CH group in each heteroaromatic ring are indistinguishable; for simplicity in refinement, these disordered groups are represented by atoms N2, N2C, N4, N4C, N6, N6C, N8, and N8C (see Figure a, upper part). Molecule B located at an inversion center is basically isostructural with A (see Figure a, lower part), but the site occupancy ratio of Ag20 and Ag21 is 0.33:0.67. The imidazole ligands that coordinate to Ag20 and Ag21 likewise exhibit pseudo-C 2h symmetry, and the disorder ligating N atom and CH group are represented by N18, N18C, N20, and N20C in structure refinement. The crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for 1–6 are given in Table 1 of the .

Single-Crystal Structure Determination

Crystal data were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K. The intensities were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors, as well as for absorption by the multiscan method. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELX-97, and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. For compound 3, bromine atom Br6 is disordered over two positions and refined with an assigned site occupancy ratio of 0.5:0.5. For 4, silver atom Ag7 and one independent 2-methylpyrazine ligand are each located at an inversion center, so that the 2-methyl substituent of the latter is disordered over two sites; furthermore, silver atom Ag1 exhibits disorder over two positions, each with half site occupancy. In addition, a CF3 moiety (F10, F11, F12, F10', F11', F12') of a trifluoroacetate group exhibits orientational disorder. For 6, there are two kinds of discrete molecules which are labeled A and B, with A located in a general position and B at a crystallographic center of symmetry. In molecule A, Ag9, Ag10, Ag11, and Ag12 are each assigned half site occupancy in least-squares refinement, and the pair of imidazole ligands that coordinate to each of them exhibit orientational disorder such that the ligating N atom and an adjacent CH group in each heteroaromatic ring are indistinguishable; for simplicity in refinement, these disordered groups are represented by atoms N2, N2C, N4, N4C, N6, N6C, N8, and N8C (see Figure a, upper part). Molecule B located at an inversion center is basically isostructural with A (see Figure a, lower part), but the site occupancy ratio of Ag20 and Ag21 is 0.33:0.67. The imidazole ligands that coordinate to Ag20 and Ag21 likewise exhibit pseudo-C 2h  symmetry, and the disorder ligating N atom and CH group are represented by N18, N18C, N20, and N20C in structure refinement. The crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for 1-6 are given in Table 1 of the .

elements.content: As reported in our previous investigation, crude Ag2C4 can be dissolved in a concentrated aqueous solution of silver ions to form [Ag4C4Ag4] moieties consolidated by argentophilic interactions. Compounds 2–6 were synthesized by dissolving crude Ag2C4 in a concentrated solution of silver trifluoroacetate/tetrafluoroborate, and different nitrogen donors were then introduced as ancillary ligands. The tetrafluoroborate ion here was employed to provide a high concentration of silver ions. Compound 1 was obtained using a similar procedure, except that silver nitrate solution was used instead.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

As reported in our previous investigation, crude Ag2C4 can be dissolved in a concentrated aqueous solution of silver ions to form [Ag4C4Ag4] moieties consolidated by argentophilic interactions. Compounds 2-6 were synthesized by dissolving crude Ag2C4 in a concentrated solution of silver trifluoroacetate/tetrafluoroborate, and different nitrogen donors were then introduced as ancillary ligands. The tetrafluoroborate ion here was employed to provide a high concentration of silver ions. Compound 1 was obtained using a similar procedure, except that silver nitrate solution was used instead.

elements.content: In compound 1, the C4 2– ion is located at an inversion center with each terminal carbon atom capped by a butterfly-shaped Ag4 basket (Figure a), wherein the silver–ethynide Ag···C mixed (σ, π) bonds are in the range of 2.143(5)–2.478(5) Ǻ, and a π-type Ag3–C2 bond has a length of 2.736(1) Ǻ. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains a 3-chloropyridine ligand and three independent nitrate groups, which may be conveniently referred to by naming their nitrogen atoms N1, N2, and N3. The three nitrate groups adopt different coordination modes to connect with the [Ag4C4Ag4] building units: a μ2-O,O′ coordinate plus O,O′ chelating mode for N1, a μ3-O,O′,O″ plus O,O′ chelating mode for N2, and a μ3-O,O′,O′ mode for N3. The [Ag4C4Ag4] aggregates arranged in a pseudohexagonal array are linked by nitrate groups to form a thick layer parallel to the bc plane (Figure b). Weak hydrogen bonds of the type Cpyridine–H···Onitrate (3.42 Ǻ) between the 3-chloropyridine ring and the nitrate oxygen atom O3 occur between adjacent coordination layers (Figure c), thus generating a three-dimensional supramolecular network.
elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structures

[{(Ag2C4)0.5(AgNO3)3(L1)}⋅H2O] n  (1; L1 = 3-Chloropyridine)

In compound 1, the C4 2- ion is located at an inversion center with each terminal carbon atom capped by a butterfly-shaped Ag4 basket (Figure a), wherein the silver-ethynide Ag⋅⋅⋅C mixed (σ, π) bonds are in the range of 2.143(5)-2.478(5) Ǻ, and a π-type  Ag3-C2 bond has a length of 2.736(1) Ǻ. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains a 3-chloropyridine ligand and three independent nitrate groups, which may be conveniently referred to by naming their nitrogen atoms N1, N2, and N3. The three nitrate groups adopt different coordination modes to connect with the [Ag4C4Ag4] building units: a μ2-O,O' coordinate plus O,O' chelating mode for N1, a μ3-O,O',O" plus O,O' chelating mode for N2, and a μ3-O,O',O' mode for N3. The [Ag4C4Ag4] aggregates arranged in a pseudohexagonal array are linked by nitrate groups to form a thick layer parallel to the bc plane (Figure b). Weak hydrogen bonds of the type Cpyridine-H⋅⋅⋅Onitrate (3.42 Ǻ) between the 3-chloropyridine ring and the nitrate oxygen atom O3 occur between adjacent coordination layers (Figure c), thus generating a three-dimensional supramolecular network.

elements.content: The building unit of compound 2 is a coordination silver chain composed of both a [Ag4C4Ag4] aggregate and a [Ag3C4Ag3] aggregate on the basis that Ag–C distances shorter than 2.6 Ǻ are taken as effective silver–ethynide bonds (Figure a). The [Ag3C4Ag3] aggregate in complex 2 is first reported herein, in contrast to the [Ag4C4Ag4] aggregate that commonly occurs in previously reported silver(I) double and multiple salts containing 1,3-butadiynediide. The first independent C4 2– ligand (C1C2C3C4) adopts a μ8 coordination mode, wherein the ethynide moiety C1C2 is surrounded by Ag1, Ag2, Ag3, and Ag4 with σ-type bond lengths in the range of 2.213(7)–2.540(7) Ǻ and a π type length at Ag3–C2 = 2.492(7) Ǻ; the other ethynide fragment C3C4 is surrounded by Ag2a, Ag7, Ag8, and Ag9 through σ interactions in the range of 2.124(7)–2.521(7) Ǻ. In contrast, the second independent C4 2‑ dianion (C5C6C7C8) exhibits an unusual μ6 coordination mode, wherein C5C6 is surrounded by Ag4, Ag5, and Ag6 through σ interactions in the range of 2.122(8)–2.420(7) Ǻ, while C7C8 is bonded to Ag9, Ag10, and Ag11 through σ interactions in the range of 2.141(8)–2.314(8) Ǻ. The [Ag4C4Ag4] and [Ag3C4Ag3] aggregates share two silver atoms (Ag4 and Ag9), and a [Ag22(C4)4] aggregate is accordingly constructed. Adjacent [Ag22(C4)4] aggregates are further linked together through a centrosymmetric silver rhomboid composed of independent atoms Ag12 and Ag13 (Ag12···Ag13 = 3.029(1) Ǻ and Ag12···Ag13c = 3.129(1) Ǻ) to yield an infinite silver chain (Figure a). Such a silver chain is coordinated by trifluoroacetate ligands, aqua ligands, and 3-chloropyridine ligands (Figure b,c). Heteroaryl π···π stacking interactions also exist between pairs of pyridine rings (centroid–centroid distance between ring I′ and ring IV 3.793 Ǻ) to stabilize the whole columnar assembly. The silver chains are interconnected by C–H···O and C–H···F hydrogen-bonding interactions to yield a three-dimensional supramolecular network (Figure d).

elements.content:
Compound 3 is isomorphous with 2, with 3-bromopyridine replacing 3-chloropyridine.

[{(Ag<sub>2</sub>C<sub>4</sub>)(AgCF<sub>3</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>5</sub>(L3)<sub>1.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>}·H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>; L3 = 2-Methylpyrazine)

The crystal structure of 4 contains two nonequivalent but similar [Ag4C4Ag4] aggregates (Figure a). Each independent C4 2– dianion is located at a crystallographic inversion center with its terminal ethynide group capped by a butterfly-shaped Ag4 basket via a μ4-η1:η1:η1:η2 mode. These two types of [Ag4C4Ag4] aggregates coalesce by sharing silver atoms of the type Ag4 and Ag1a to generate a silver coordination column along the a axis, which is stabilized by trifluoroacetate, aqua, and 2-methylpyrazine (L3) ligands (Figure b). Of this silver coordination column, Ag5 and Ag6 are each coordinated by an aqua ligand (O1W and O2W, respectively), while Ag6 is also coordinated by a L3 ligand. The silver column is further linked to an external silver atom Ag7 by two trifluoroacetate groups (O1–O2 and O3–O4) through a μ-O,O bridging mode and a μ4-O,O,O′,O′ ligation mode, respectively. The linkage of adjacent coordination silver columns through this external silver atom Ag7 and two 2-methylpyrazine ligands (types LI and LII) generates a three-dimensional coordination network (Figure c). A solvated water molecule of type O3W is located inside an infinite channel along the a direction in this three-dimensional coordination network, and it is attached to the silver coordination column by hydrogen bonding (O3W–H3WB···O8 and O1W–H1WA···O3W).

elements.content: Introduction of the bidentate ligand 2-cyanopyridine as a structure-directing agent led to generation of discrete molecules in compound 5. In the unit cell of complex 5, there are two isostructural centrosymmetric [Ag4C4Ag4] aggregates designated as A and B (Figure a). In the representative aggregate A, each terminus of C4 2– is capped by a Ag4 basket through σ-type silver–ethynide interactions ranging from 2.192(6) to 2.341(7) Ǻ and a mixed (σ, π) interaction of 2.761(1) Ǻ between Ag2 and C2 (Figure a). Silver aggregate A is further stabilized by the coordination of three independent peripheral μ2-O,O′ trifluoroacetate ligands at each [Ag4CC] terminal with Ag–O bond distances in the range of 2.283(6)–2.379(5) Ǻ. Six 2-cyanopyridines act in the μ2-N,N′ ligation mode to bridge the two terminal Ag4 aggregates, thus forming a hexakis(heteroaromatic ligand)-bridged, 1,3-butadiyne-1,4-diide -encapsulated (F3CCO2)3Ag4⊂CCCC⊃Ag4(O2CCF3)3 coordination molecular cluster. The two kinds of silver clusters (types A and B) are interlinked through C–H···O hydrogen bonding to yield a three-dimensional network (Figure b,c).

elements.content: Compound 6 comprises two kinds of [Ag4C4Ag4] aggregates, labeled A and B, the latter being located at an inversion center (Figure a). Differing from the aforementioned five compounds, the terminal ethynides in 6 each coordinate to a planar Ag4 segment instead of a butterfly-shaped Ag4 basket. Such a planar CC–M4 coordination mode has been reported for transition metals, but to our knowledge there is only one literature example of a planar CC–Ag4 system, which exists in the compound [Ag16(C4)(C2F5­CO2)16­(H2O)8]·2H3O+·14H2O. In silver aggregate A, the terminal ethynide C1C2 bonds to a planar Ag4 segment (defined by Ag1, Ag2, Ag3, and Ag4) through a μ4-η1:η1:η1:η1 bonding mode with bond distances varying from 2.263(1) to 2.386(1) Å. Ethynide C3C4 similarly attaches to a planar Ag4 segment (defined by Ag5, Ag6, Ag7, and Ag8) in the range of 2.248(1)–2.566(2) Å. Each Ag4 segment is consolidated by five trifluoroacetate ligands, four of which each span a Ag···Ag edge in a μ2-O,O′ coordination mode. The fifth trifluoroacetate (O9–O10), which is located on the opposite side of the C1C2 moiety, connects the silver quadrangle (Ag1–Ag2–Ag3–Ag4) to an external silver atom (Ag13) in a μ4-O,O,O′,O′ coordination mode. A similar coordination scenario also applies to ethynide C3C4. As shown in Figure a, the two external silver atoms Ag13 and Ag14 are each linearly coordinated by two imidazole ligands. In addition to this pair of ordered “external” (imid)2Ag units, there is a pair of disordered “internal” (imid)2Ag units that lie between the planar Ag4 segment. The latter set of bis(imidazole)-bound silver atoms (Ag9, Ag10, Ag11, and Ag12, each having a site occupancy factor of 1:2) connect to the outer Ag4 quadrangles by Ag···Ag interactions in the range 3.166(2)–3.372(2) Å. The imidazole ligands attached to the disordered silver atoms exhibit orientational disorder such that each heteroaromatic ring possesses an apparent C 2h axis about the N–H bond with its ligating N atom and a CH unit occupying equivalent positions with half site occupancy (Figure a, upper part). Centrosymmetric silver aggregate B is isostructural with aggregate A, except for minor differences in molecular geometry (Figure a, lower part). These two kinds of silver aggregates are arranged in an AABAA... pattern along the [011] direction and interconnected through hydrogen bonding between the imidazole-NH and trifluoroacetate-O atoms to form a layer parallel to the bc plane (Figure b). Adjacent layers are packed and further linked by multiple intermolecular F···F interactions to form a three-dimensional supramolecular network (Figure d).

elements.content: The observed IR spectra of compounds 1–6 exhibit νCC absorption maxima in the range 2058–2111 cm–1, which have no clear correlation with variation in their crystal structures. In contrast, the νCC stretching frequencies of a series of 14 silver(I) double and multiple salts containing 1,3-butadiyne-1,4-diide previously reported by our group show IR frequencies from 2043 to 2083 cm–1. A rational explanation of the νCC blue shift in 1–6 is that they all contain ancillary heteroaromatic N-donor sites that strongly coordinate to the silver atoms, thereby resulting in weakening of the Ag–C bonding interaction and a concomitant increase in the frequency of the CC stretching vibration.
elements.clean_text:
νCC IR Frequencies of 1,3-Butadiyne-1,4-diide

The observed IR spectra of compounds 1-6 exhibit νCC absorption maxima in the range 2058-2111 cm-1, which have no clear correlation with variation in their crystal structures. In contrast, the νCC stretching frequencies of a series of 14 silver(I) double and multiple salts containing 1,3-butadiyne-1,4-diide previously reported by our group show IR frequencies from 2043 to 2083 cm-1. A rational explanation of the νCC blue shift in 1-6 is that they all contain ancillary heteroaromatic N-donor sites that strongly coordinate to the silver atoms, thereby resulting in weakening of the Ag-C bonding interaction and a concomitant increase in the frequency of the CC stretching vibration.

elements.content: In summary, directed by a series of heteroaromatic N-donor ligands, new coordination compounds based on the multinuclear silver 1,3-butadiynediide cluster synthon Ag n ⊂CCCC⊃Ag n (n = 3, 4) that vary in structure from discrete molecules to dimensionalities of one to three have been constructed. In 5 and 6, six 2-cyanopyridine ligands and two bis(imidazole)silver units, respectively, are each bound to the inner positions of a central [Ag4C4Ag4] cluster and serve as terminal stoppers to prevent further aggregation between such silver clusters, thereby yielding discrete polynuclear molecules. In isomporphous complexes 2 and 3, silver columns generated by ladderlike 1,3-butadiynediide linkage units are consolidated by peripheral 3-chloropyridine and 3-bromopyridine groups, respectively, which function as terminal ligands to retain the linear dimensionality of the resulting structure. When the linear bidentate ligand 2-methylpyrazine is employed in 4, the silver columns generated from 1,3-butadiynediide are connected to form a three-dimensional coordination network. In complex 1, the silver aggregates are linked by nitrate groups to form a layer structure wherein the 3-chloropyridine ligands coordinate to silver atoms at the upper and lower surfaces of each layer to prevent further connection between stacked layers to form a higher-dimensional structure. The present study has demonstrated that a variety of discrete molecular and higher-dimensional structures can be constructed by linking [Ag4C4Ag4] cluster aggregates with mono- or bidentate nitrogen-donor ligands. This study sheds some light on further investigation of the influence of diverse types of ligands on network assembly based on the multinuclear Ag4⊂CCCC⊃Ag4 supramolecular synthon.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, directed by a series of heteroaromatic N-donor ligands, new coordination compounds based on the multinuclear silver 1,3-butadiynediide cluster synthon Ag n ⊂CCCC⊃Ag n  (n = 3, 4) that vary in structure from discrete molecules to dimensionalities of one to three have been constructed. In 5 and 6, six 2-cyanopyridine ligands and two bis(imidazole)silver units, respectively, are each bound to the inner positions of a central [Ag4C4Ag4] cluster and serve as terminal stoppers to prevent further aggregation between such silver clusters, thereby yielding discrete polynuclear molecules. In isomporphous complexes 2 and 3, silver columns generated by ladderlike 1,3-butadiynediide linkage units are consolidated by peripheral 3-chloropyridine and 3-bromopyridine groups, respectively, which function as terminal ligands to retain the linear dimensionality of the resulting structure. When the linear bidentate ligand 2-methylpyrazine is employed in 4, the silver columns generated from 1,3-butadiynediide are connected to form a three-dimensional coordination network. In complex 1, the silver aggregates are linked by nitrate groups to form a layer structure wherein the 3-chloropyridine ligands coordinate to silver atoms at the upper and lower surfaces of each layer to prevent further connection between stacked layers to form a higher-dimensional structure. The present study has demonstrated that a variety of discrete molecular and higher-dimensional structures can be constructed by linking [Ag4C4Ag4] cluster aggregates with mono- or bidentate nitrogen-donor ligands. This study sheds some light on further investigation of the influence of diverse types of ligands on network assembly based on the multinuclear Ag4⊂CCCC⊃Ag4 supramolecular synthon.

elements.content:
The authors declare no competing financial interest.

References

In our working model, the terminal carbon atom bearing the negative charge draws neighboring Ag(I) atoms together to facilitate the onset of argentophilic interactions, such that the multinuclear silver–ethynide binding interaction is considered to be mainly ionic with minor covalent σ and π components. Therefore, the designation of “silver–ethynide bonds” of σ or mixed (σ, π) type should not be taken as normal covalent or coordination bonds.

References

In our working model, the terminal carbon atom bearing the negative charge draws neighboring Ag(I) atoms together to facilitate the onset of argentophilic interactions, such that the multinuclear silver-ethynide binding interaction is considered to be mainly ionic with minor covalent σ and π components. Therefore, the designation of "silver-ethynide bonds" of σ or mixed (σ, π) type should not be taken as normal covalent or coordination bonds.

Caution! Ag2C4 should be stored wet in the dark at −10 °C, and only a small quantity should be used for subsequent synthesis.

[{(Ag<sub>2</sub>C<sub>4</sub>)<sub>0.5</sub>(AgNO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub>(L1)}·H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>; L1 = 3-Chloropyridine)

Moist Ag2C4 (∼110 mg) was added to a concentrated aqueous solution (1 mL) of AgNO3 (0.44 g, 2 mmol) in a beaker, and the mixture was stirred until the solution reached saturation. The excess Ag2C4 was filtered off, and a few drops of 3-chloropyridine were added to the filtrate. The solution was then placed in a refrigerator at −10 °C. After a few days, transparent yellow platelike crystals of 1 (∼65%) were deposited and collected. Compound 1 decomposes above 93 °C. IR: ν 2065 cm–1 (w, νCC). Anal. Calcd for C7H6Ag4ClN4O10 (M r = 773.09): C, 10.88; H, 0.78; N, 7.25. Found: C, 11.35; H, 0.92; N, 7.58.

[(Ag<sub>2</sub>C<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(AgCF<sub>3</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>9</sub>(L1)<sub>7</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>; L1 = 3-Chloropyridine)

Moist Ag2C4 (∼110 mg) was added to a concentrated aqueous solution (1 mL) of AgCF3CO2 (0.44 g, 2 mmol) and AgBF4 (0.380 g, 2 mmol) in a beaker, and the mixture was stirred until the solution was saturated. The excess Ag2C4 was filtered off, and a few drops of 3-chloropyridine were added to the filtrate. The solution was placed in a refrigerator at −10 °C. After a few days, the transparent yellow blocklike crystals of 2 (∼46%) that had deposited were collected. Compound 2 decomposes above 120 °C. IR: ν 2065 cm–1 (w, νCC). Anal. Calcd for C61H30Ag13Cl7F27N7O19 (M r = 3328.38): C, 16.52; H, 0.94; N, 2.69. Found: C, 16.77; H, 0.90; N, 2.60.

[(Ag<sub>2</sub>C<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(AgCF<sub>3</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>9</sub>(L2)<sub>7</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>; L2 = 3-Bromopyridine)

The previous synthetic procedure for 2 was repeated, except that 3-bromopyridine was used instead of 3-chloropyridine. The solution was placed in a refrigerator at −10 °C. After a few days, transparent yellow blocklike crystals of 3 (∼63%) that had deposited were collected. Compound 3 decomposes above 120 °C. IR: ν 2094 cm–1 (w, νCC). Anal. Calcd for C61H30Ag13Br7F27N7O19 (M r = 3639.60): C, 20.13; H, 0.83; N, 2.69. Found: C, 20.51; H, 0.94; N, 2.88.

[{(Ag<sub>2</sub>C<sub>4</sub>)(AgCF<sub>3</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>5</sub>(L3)<sub>1.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>}·H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>; L3 = 2-Methylpyrazine)

Moist Ag2C4 (∼160 mg) was added to a concentrated aqueous solution (1 mL) of AgCF3CO2 (0.585 g, 2.5 mmol) and AgBF4 (0.190 g, 1 mmol) in a beaker, and the mixture was stirred until the solution was saturated. The excess Ag2C4 was filtered off, and a few drops of 2-methylpyrazine were added to the filtrate. The solution was placed in a refrigerator at −10 °C. After a few days, transparent yellow platelike crystals of 4 (∼10%) were deposited. Compound 4 decomposes above 180 °C. IR: ν 2058 cm–1 (w, νCC). Anal. Calcd for C43H29Ag14F30N6O26 (M r = 3125.90): C, 16.52; H, 0.94; N, 2.69. Found: C, 16.77; H, 0.90; N, 2.60.

[(Ag<sub>2</sub>C<sub>4</sub>)(AgCF<sub>3</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>6</sub>(L4)<sub>6</sub>] (<bold>5</bold>; L4 = 2-Cyanopyridine)

The synthetic procedure of 1 was repeated with 2-cyanopyridine replacing 3-chloropyridine. The solution was placed in a refrigerator at −10 °C. After a few days, the transparent yellow blocklike crystals of 5 (∼36%) that had deposited were collected. Compound 5 decomposes above 93 °C. IR: ν 2111 cm–1 (w, νCC). Anal. Calcd for C52H36Ag8F18N12O18 (M r = 2321.84): C, 26.90; H, 1.04; N, 7.24. Found: C, 26.60; H, 1.28; N, 7.48.

[(Ag<sub>2</sub>C<sub>4</sub>)(AgCF<sub>3</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>10</sub>(L5)<sub>8</sub>] (<bold>6</bold>; L5 = Imidazole)

Moist Ag2C4 (∼110 mg) was added to a concentrated aqueous solution (1 mL) of AgCF3CO2 (0.44 g, 2 mmol) and AgBF4 (0.380 g, 2 mmol) in a beaker, and the mixture was stirred until the solution was saturated. The excess Ag2C4 was filtered off. To the clear filtrate was added 0.5 mL of a methanol solution containing dissolved imidazole (0.015 g, 0.22 mmol). The resulting solution was placed in a refrigerator at −10 °C. After a few days, the transparent yellow blocklike crystals of 6 (∼5%) that had deposited were collected. Compound 6 decomposes above 79 °C. IR: ν 2080 cm–1 (w, νCC). Anal. Calcd for C48H32Ag12F30N16O20 (M r = 3017.34): C, 19.11; H, 1.07; N, 7.43. Found: C, 18.90; H, 0.93; N, 7.12.
